koohiiStory2: The axe-wielding maniac nails a poor victim, right under a cliff. Blood everywhere! (thanks scottamus!).
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The axe radical and the axe kanji are exactly the same, with one minor difference. This kanji is also used as the bread loaf counter, probably because bread was so big and hard in the past that they had to use axes to slice them.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Imagine you've gone back in time a good hundred years, and you're trying to count loaves of bread after each swing of your axe. Axes and bread loaves will become intertwined in your brain.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: You imagined being back in time too good and now you're stuck using an axe to be a bread loaf counter for the King (ãã‚“) of England. You aren't sure which king he is or when in time you are, but he's mean and keeps eating all the bread you cut up with your axe.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Imagine being stuck using an axe on bread while the King of England glares down at you, munching and spilling crumbs everywhere.

chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: One catty is a half kilogram which is the weight of this tomahawk.
origin_of_ch_char_book: There were many wars and battles during the Shang Dynasty (16th century â€“ 11th century BC). Thus, people often came up with ideas for weapons and for battle strategies when fighting with neighboring countries. (å…µ, bing, arms) contains a shape of an axe (æ–¤, jin, a unit of weightï¼›original shape is , left is a tree caved in, right is an ax) and two hands in a clasped . It is an image of someone wielding an axe.,This axe is also a part of another word (æ–°, xin=hsin, new). This word has a pointy blade and a tree (æœ¨, mu, tree) beneath it, and an axe cutting the tree (æ–¤, jin, a unit of weight). Something cut by an axe roughly was an unit of weight before, and now this unit is used as an important unit of weight (500g).
humanum_full_description_en:
A golden inscription like a crank axe, the original meaning is an axe for logging. The " jin " in oracle bone inscriptions consists of the handle of a crank axe and the sharp blade of an arrow. The original meaning of " jin " is an axe. In inscriptions, the axe blade and the axe handle are written separately, and the pictographic meaning is gradually lost. Later, from the " burden " of the word " burden " remains next to the ax of justice, as " analysis ", " discount ", " chop ", " chop ." The term " jin " in weights and measures is just a pretext.

"Shuowen": "Jin, weeping wood. Pictogram. Every kind of catty belongs to Jin." Duan Yucai's note: "Axe for weaving wood is called an axe. Horizontal one It is like an axe, and straight is like a handle." Wang Jun "Shu Wenju Reading": "Jin's blade is horizontal, and axe's blade is vertical." That is to say, the direction of the blade of " Jin " and the direction of the handle intersect, which is equivalent to later generations. The adze (Shen Pei).

The meaning of Oracle is unknown. Bronze writing is used as a place name, and it is called "cai (in) jin". Also used as a unit of weight, the prince Zhongfu Ding: "four catties and twelve taels."

The bamboo slips of the Warring States Period are a cautious " respect ." Ji Kangzi asks about Confucius" Jane 7: "He who is righteous and righteous, he will act with jin (cautious)." It means that etiquette is used to restrain the gentleman's behavior and make him be cautious in his words and deeds.

Han silk script is used as a unit of weight, "Mawangdui silk script. "Health Prescription" line 141: "Use plaster for less than half a catty."
humanum_short_description_en: A gold inscription like a crank axe, the original meaning is an axe used for logging.

This word has a pointy blade and a tree (æœ¨, mu, tree) beneath it, and an axe cutting the tree (æ–¤, jin, a unit of weight). Something cut by an axe roughly was an unit of weight before, and now this unit is used as an important unit of weight (500g).

A golden inscription like a crank axe, the original meaning is an axe for logging. The " jin" in oracle bone inscriptions consists of the handle of a crank axe and the sharp blade of an arrow. The original meaning of " jin" is an axe. In inscriptions, the axe blade and the axe handle are written separately, and the pictographic meaning is gradually lost. Later, from the " burden" of the word " burden" remains next to the ax of justice, as " analysis", " discount", " chop", " chop." The term " jin" in weights and measures is just a pretext. "Shuowen": "Jin, weeping wood. Pictogram. Every kind of catty belongs to Jin." Duan Yucai's note: "Axe for weaving wood is called an axe. Horizontal one It is like an axe, and straight is like a handle." Wang Jun "Shu Wenju Reading": "Jin's blade is horizontal, and axe's blade is vertical." That is to say, the direction of the blade of " Jin" and the direction of the handle intersect, which is equivalent to later generations. The adze (Shen Pei). The meaning of Oracle is unknown. Bronze writing is used as a place name, and it is called "cai (in) jin". Also used as a unit of weight, the prince Zhongfu Ding: "four catties and twelve taels." The bamboo slips of the Warring States Period are a cautious " respect." Ji Kangzi asks about Confucius" Jane 7: "He who is righteous and righteous, he will act with jin (cautious)." It means that etiquette is used to restrain the gentleman's behavior and make him be cautious in his words and deeds. Han silk script is used as a unit of weight, "Mawangdui silk script. "Health Prescription" line 141: "Use plaster for less than half a catty."

Chinese municipal unit of weight: two catties. Jinjin (over-calculation of trivial or irrelevant things, such as "calculus").
The ancient tool for felling trees: axe.

Chinese dictionary definition of words
[â‘ ]ï¼»jÄ«nï¼½
["Guang Yun" Ju Xinqie, Ping Xin, see you. ]
(1) Axe.
(2) Refers to weapons.
(3) Chop; Chop.
(4) It refers to the deletion and modification of words. See "jinzheng", "jin axe".
(5) Weight unit. In the old system, one catty is divided into 16 taels, and the city system is divided into 12 catties. It's half a kilogram.
(6) It is used to add to the name of an object measured by jin, as the collective name of the object.
(7) A farm tool that is as small as a hoe.

Radicals: æ–¤  (axe)
Meaning Mnemonic
The axe radical and the axe kanji are exactly the same, with one minor difference. This kanji is also used as the bread loaf counter, probably because bread was so big and hard in the past that they had to use axes to slice them.
Imagine you've gone back in time a good hundred years, and you're trying to count loaves of bread after each swing of your axe. Axes and bread loaves will become intertwined in your brain.
Reading Mnemonic
You imagined being back in time too good and now you're stuck using an axe to be a bread loaf counter for the King (ãã‚“) of England. You aren't sure which king he is or when in time you are, but he's mean and keeps eating all the bread you cut up with your axe.
Imagine being stuck using an axe on bread while the King of England glares down at you, munching and spilling crumbs everywhere.
